content.question:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

The circuit shown above is constructed with two <math alttext="6.0 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> batteries and three resistors with the values shown. The currents <math alttext="I sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="I sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="I sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and in each branch of the circuit are indicated.

(a)

i. Using Kirchhoff’s rules, write, but DO NOT SOLVE, equations that can be used to solve for the current in each resistor.

frqParts.text:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

The circuit shown above is constructed with two <math alttext="6.0 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> batteries and three resistors with the values shown. The currents <math alttext="I sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="I sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="I sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and in each branch of the circuit are indicated.

(a)

i. Using Kirchhoff’s rules, write, but DO NOT SOLVE, equations that can be used to solve for the current in each resistor.

ii. Calculate the current in the <math alttext="200 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor.

iii. Calculate the power dissipated by the <math alttext="200 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor.

The two <math alttext="6.0 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> batteries are replaced with a battery with voltage <math alttext="E m f" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow></math> and a resistor of resistance <math alttext="50 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , as shown above. The voltmeter <math alttext="volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> shows that the voltage across the <math alttext="200 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor is <math alttext="4.4 volts " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Calculate the current through the <math alttext="50 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor.
(c) Calculate the voltage <math alttext="E m f" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow></math> of the battery.

(d)

i. The <math alttext="200 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor in the circuit in Figure 2 is replaced with a <math alttext="200 microfarads" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> capacitor, as shown on the right, and the circuit is allowed to reach steady state. Calculate the current through the <math alttext="50 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor.

ii. The <math alttext="200 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor in the circuit in Figure 2 is replaced with an ideal <math alttext="50 millihenrys " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> inductor, as shown on the right, and the circuit is allowed to reach steady state. Is the current in the <math alttext="50 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor greater than, less than, or equal to the current calculated in part (b)?

Greater than Less than Equal to

Justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
